Here's the rule of under-regulated markets. When there's no transparency and lots of money, you can be sure there are problem no one in the industry in question wants the public to know about. Secrecy is a sure sign of wrongdoing. The more money to be had, the worse it is.

The town of Mansfield, La.(DeSoto Parish) has emerged from poverty due to natural gas exploration in the Haynesville shale. New schools and churches are being constructed from increased tax revenue, bonus payments and royalties. Two new hotels were recently built in Mansfield. Elementary school teachers' starting salaries hover around $45,000 per year. Jobs are being created, money is being spent in this small town. This once depressed NW Louisiana economy now has hope...hope for a future, families paying off debt, spending money locally, and planning for their children's college. I am an environmentalist. I own an organic/natural landscape design business and I support American natural gas. American natural gas exploration creates jobs for Americans. Lets end our reliance on OPEC and support natural gas.

This problem has vexed travelers for the past decade and a half and there are no tidy solutions yet. By its very nature, making a call or using the phone to check emails or websites will always require no fewer than two providers, the overseas company – that you use there, and your home company – that bills you. To get mad at your local company is misdirecting your anger.

I have lived and travel overseas extensively for almost 20 years. I agree that services like Skype tend to be better than buying a local SIM when overseas. You tend to use wi-fi (which tends to be free from local 'hot spots') for access, then use Skype for transport to the country you’re calling, and the local country’s rates to terminate to the number you call. The article has an inaccuracy: it assumes that your call to phones will be around 2c/min. Not so. They will vary by country. For example, if you call a cell phone in Dublin, expect to pay almost 22c/min, in Dubai it will be closer to 28c/min, in Hanoi almost 34c/min. Count yourself lucky if you call a country and pay 2c/m.

Mobile calling on your phone is a paradox: the seller of service (the overseas telecom company) does not see, much less treat you as their customer, ever. You are transient prey, and there is no business case whatsoever for them to provide lower rates. Just the opposite exists; they see you as a 'red meat' revenue opportunity with enough barriers to prevent you moving to alternatives. Markups (the price you pay divided by the costs) are staggering; often more than several hundred percent for voice calls, and thousands of percent for text messages. A vast majority of users don’t understand this until they see their first statement after a trip – they will be angry, but at the wrong person...
Nuke Verizon AND Jamaica, $1000 for 50 megs of data (I go thru 50 megs in 20 minutes 24 x 7 x 365 for 45 a month) is AN ACT OF WAR. Sort out which of the two were guilty after killing them both.
Hey, SM. 2 words: Husker Du. Maybe 2 more: Killing Joke. I love Nirvana, but they didn't appear out of the void.

They have a pretty uphill battle in an increasingly crowded space (iOS, Android WebOS, etc.). I'd wish them luck but for the longest time I waited and waited for my BlackBerry to be updated with a better browser and better features than just real-time email or BBM and finally Apple came along with the iPhone and showed them how it's done. Long live the iPhone and long live Steve Jobs!

Stop taxing the savings of New Yorkers and you can produce the desired result - more investment in real property and reversal of the outflow of population. If New York Counties, Towns and Schools continue to fund themselves with real estate taxes based upon fabricated valuations, tax rates created to serve wasteful and unresponsive expenditure then we know what the future will bring  - continued erosion of your savings you have unfortunately placed in your homes that are treated as nothing other then an annuity by your local governments. The most regressive tax we have here is real estate tax and its replacement is due now. What makes it so regressive is the fact that the vast majority of the middle class own a major portion of their assets in real property where the wealthy do not and who can blame them. Let the middle class pay the property "wealth" tax while we are content to pay taxes on income, dividends, capital gains and interest but never on assets!

Amazed by the number of comments against our involvement in Libya. We got involved reluctantly, at the very last minute, in response to the desperate requests of Libyans who, inspired by the popular uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt, were about to be slaughtered because they dared question the Qaddafi dictatorship. If we'd done nothing many of my fellow commentors, from the comfort of their safe and secure homes, would now just as energetically be saying, "How could the US not have intervened?" Gee whiz ...

In response to the outcry about focusing specifically on men, and for doling out city funds for this program in a time of fiscal austerity, please consider this: Spending money on education and empowerment for groups inordinately prone to incarceration pays off in the not-that-long run. Why spend $40K per year to keep one of these guys despondent and unproductive at Rikers when he could be equipped with the skills to become a contributing member of society for a heck of a lot less?

And before you tell these young men to rise up on their own, visit the places where they've grown up: some of the most uninspiring communities in America. Visit their elementary schools. Spend a day sitting in a welfare office. Shop at their grocery stores. Take the time to imagine what it feels like to live in their New York and think of what could happen if we treated people like people, regardless of whether they live in the projects or Upper West.

In many situations, it seems that Facebook minimizes the spectrum and depth of human emotion and makes already difficult situations worse. I'm glad I got past my teens before it really took off.

Friendships can survive break-ups. But they won't always, and say friendship is a 'healthy' practice without acknowledging that it isn't the only healthy mechanism of recovery ignores the need of mourning time. Feelings are inevitably hurt in a breakup and even as a teenager, there is a profound sense of loss when you lose intimacy with someone you cared about. To brush that under the rug and act as if it isn't valid to feel sad, hurt and angry is crazy.

Defriending someone on facebook may not be a vindictive act -- maybe it's just upsetting to see their page, maybe you need to get away from it. Certainly it's an understandable move and one that can be part of a normal grieving process.

Grieving is different for everyone, but I think that rather than defining certain breakups as 'good' or 'bad' (who really knows, anyhow, except the people in them?) a better lesson comes with helping teens learn how to acknowledge the loss, honor their feelings and method of grieving, remain respectful towards a former parter (this doesn't have to be friendship) and move back towards functioning happily in their life.

I'm happy for these young men to get help, however the help shows up. There was a period in America, when jobs training programs and support were much more prevalent. We need to get more such models going. Teaching young people their value and work skills is much cheaper than prison.

And this is the result of the remnants of the sixties, let it all hang out, mindset, destroying a generation. #12

This program doesn't address the real issue facing young black and hispanic men. Mainly that the police are allowed to stop and frisk them, and search and seize their property without reasonable suspicion or probable cause. This in turn leads to the high numbers of incarceration among that population.

The money and influence is being thrown at the wrong side of the equation. Actually, since the police keep arresting people for minor drug possession and prosecutors keep forcing them to plead guilty to avoid minimum mandatory sentences, then programs like Bloomberg's will always be needed. But they may not be so necessary if the harsh drug laws and penalties change.

There is no simple remedy. No magic pill. What was passed was nothing more than a joke on the American People. We must reduce spending, attrition alone will cut 3-5% per year. Though we need to cut everywhere but in a effective and distinct manner. All lopholes need to be closed. Everyone must pay their share. Obviously the wealthiest will carry a larger portion of the burden.
Our government should not be the largest employer. Security and safety should NOT be shelved, however ever dollar spent needs to be scurtinized and confirmed valid.
As a nation we have spent beyond our means. What sense does it make that we borrow $0.42 per $1.00 spent. That is absurd. Live within our means and spend less than what we take in. Raising taxes will not resolve the issue until we cut the spending. If we were able to cut $3 dollars for every dollar raised in taxes that would be prudent and supported by the people. All this Congress and the the President did is act like they did something. I believe that defense can be cut by up to 30% without dire effects. This approach would be true for all departments and expenditures. As a people we must strat NOW to fix the problem, why wait another day to start.

His Bloomberg terminals are the nerve center of a financial system that has done incalculable damage to the global economy and pushed millions into poverty. The mayor's personal fortune based on his majority ownership in Bloomberg has doubled during his first seven years in office. It's nice that he's giving back a small amount of the fortune he's amassed but it's still a drop in the bucket.

It would be far more meaningful and productive if the mayor used his bully pulpit to push back against the banks that have foreclosed on so many homes and become an agent for sound financial policy. I'd like to see him stand up for a strong Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and meaningful derivatives reform.

Of course, the mayor will do none of these things because he's a businessman first, a politician second, and a philanthropist when it suits him. In the end, he's just another oligarch who can afford to buy goodwill.
